articles.headline: On Terror, Gentle Hand or Iron Fist
articles.snippet: President Obama argued that human rights, tolerance and dialogue could combat terrorism, but his audience included representatives from some of the world’s least democratic countries.
articles.abstract: President Obama argued that human rights, tolerance and dialogue could combat terrorism, but his audience included representatives from some of the world’s least democratic countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As he sought to rally the world behind a renewed attack on terrorism, President Obama argued on Thursday that force of arms was not enough and called on all nations to “put an end to the cycle of hate” by expanding human rights, religious tolerance and peaceful dialogue.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: U.S. Muslims Take On ISIS’ Recruiting Machine
articles.snippet: The rise of the Islamic State and its recruitment efforts have jolted Muslim communities in the United States into action.
articles.abstract: The rise of the Islamic State and its recruitment efforts have jolted Muslim communities in the United States into action.
articles.lead_paragraph: STERLING, Va. — Imam Mohamed Magid tries to stay in regular contact with the teenager who came to him a few months ago, at his family’s urging, to discuss how he was being wooed by online recruiters working for the Islamic State, the extremist group in Syria and Iraq.

articles.headline: American Express Violated Antitrust Laws, Judge Rules
articles.snippet: The company has long barred merchants from encouraging customers to pay with credit cards that charge lower fees.
articles.abstract: The company has long barred merchants from encouraging customers to pay with credit cards that charge lower fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled on Thursday that a longstanding practice by American Express aimed at keeping customers from using other forms of payment violates United States antitrust laws.

articles.headline: An American Sniper, His Killer, and Deep Scars Bared for a Jury
articles.snippet: Chris Kyle, a celebrated Navy SEAL sniper, and Eddie Ray Routh, the fellow veteran who killed him, both struggled when they came home from the war.
articles.abstract: Chris Kyle, a celebrated Navy SEAL sniper, and Eddie Ray Routh, the fellow veteran who killed him, both struggled when they came home from the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: STEPHENVILLE, Tex. — They went to high school in the same Dallas suburb. They served in the same war. They both came back home mentally bruised and struggling to find their footing.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Kathryn Jones

articles.headline: Trappings of Chinese New Year Left at Sea by West Coast Port Dispute
articles.snippet: Business in both the United States and Hong Kong is being hampered by delays in trans-Pacific shipments of food and festive items.
articles.abstract: Business in both the United States and Hong Kong is being hampered by delays in trans-Pacific shipments of food and festive items.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mung beans, sticky rice and banana leaves. Confetti and little red envelopes for gift money.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: In Corporate Crimes, Individual Accountability Is Elusive
articles.snippet: Thanks to Brandon L. Garrett, author of “Too Big to Jail,” we know the notion that the government has been lax on corporate wrongdoers isn’t just folk wisdom.
articles.abstract: Thanks to Brandon L. Garrett, author of “Too Big to Jail,” we know the notion that the government has been lax on corporate wrongdoers isn’t just folk wisdom.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We have never hesitated to investigate and prosecute any individual, institution or organization that attempted to exploit our markets and take advantage of the American people,” Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. proclaimed this month when the Justice Department announced that Standard & Poor’s, the ratings agency, had agreed to pay $1.375 billion to settle civil charges that it inflated ratings on mortgage-backed securities at the heart of the financial crisis.

articles.headline: Critics in G.O.P. Say Chris Christie Is in a ‘Bubble’
articles.snippet: Conservative donors, including those who once encouraged Gov. Chris Christie to seek the White House, say the governor’s style has driven them to support others.
articles.abstract: Conservative donors, including those who once encouraged Gov. Chris Christie to seek the White House, say the governor’s style has driven them to support others.
articles.lead_paragraph: He does not return phone calls. He does not ask for support. He arrives late for meetings. And he acts as if he has all the time in the world.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: Tech Investors Create a Billion-Dollar-Baby Boom
articles.snippet: Less than a year after Snapchat was valued at about $10 billion, the hunt is on for the next proverbial “unicorn,” a nascent business worth $1 billion or more — on paper, at least.
articles.abstract: Less than a year after Snapchat was valued at about $10 billion, the hunt is on for the next proverbial “unicorn,” a nascent business worth $1 billion or more — on paper, at least.
articles.lead_paragraph: What a difference a year makes.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Children, Caged for Effect, to Mimic Imagery of ISIS
articles.snippet: Broadcast to frighten and manipulate, the Islamic State’s flamboyant violence consumes the world’s attention while more familiar threats kill far more people.
articles.abstract: Broadcast to frighten and manipulate, the Islamic State’s flamboyant violence consumes the world’s attention while more familiar threats kill far more people.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The killings have been both deliberately lurid and strangely intimate. Designed for broadcast, they have helped the Islamic State militant group build a brand of violence that shocks with its extreme brutality, yet feels as close to viewers as the family images on their smartphones.

articles.headline: Eurozone Officials Reach Accord With Greece to Extend Bailout
articles.snippet: European finance ministers announced the agreement after an emergency meeting, giving Greece breathing room on its economic and financial troubles.
articles.abstract: European finance ministers announced the agreement after an emergency meeting, giving Greece breathing room on its economic and financial troubles.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Ending an acrimonious standoff, European leaders hashed out a deal on Friday to extend Greece’s bailout by four months, giving the troubled country a financial lifeline and avoiding a bankruptcy with potentially destabilizing consequences for the region.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and James Kanter
